questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient with chronic low back pain and morning stiffness presents with acute onset of pain, redness, and photophobia in the left eye. Which HLA type is most commonly associated with this condition?

choices.text: Sorbitol accumulation in retinal ganglion cells leading to apoptosis
Loss of capillary pericytes with focal dilation of capillary walls
Increased VEGF production causing breakdown of blood-retinal barrier
Advanced glycation end products causing thickening of Bruch's membrane

questions.text: A 55-year-old type 2 diabetic patient with poor glycemic control for 15 years presents with gradual vision loss. Fundus examination reveals microaneurysms and dot-blot hemorrhages. Which of the following mechanisms is the primary cellular pathology underlying the development of microaneurysms in diabetic retinopathy?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Loss of capillary pericytes with focal dilation of capillary walls

choices.text: Central retinal artery penetrates the optic nerve sheath inferonasally about 10mm behind the eyeball
Some fibers of superior rectus muscle are adherent to the dural sheath of the intraorbital optic nerve
The optic nerve is closely surrounded by the annulus of Zinn near the optic foramen posteriorly
The intraorbital optic nerve has a slightly sinuous S-shaped course to allow eye movements

questions.text: A 28-year-old female with suspected optic neuritis complains of severe retrobulbar pain that worsens with eye movements, particularly on looking upward and downward. Which anatomical feature of the optic nerve best explains this characteristic pain pattern?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Some fibers of superior rectus muscle are adherent to the dural sheath of the intraorbital optic nerve

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient undergoes retinoscopy from a distance of 1 meter without cycloplegia. The neutralization reflex shows +3.0 DS -1.0 DC at 160°. What is the patient's actual refractive error?

choices.text: Compound hypermetropic astigmatism with the rule; both focal lines (Points B and F) are behind the retina with Point B further back than Point F
Mixed astigmatism with the rule; Point B (first focal line) is in front of the retina and Point F (second focal line) is behind the retina
Simple myopic astigmatism with the rule; Point B (first focal line) is on the retina and Point F (second focal line) is in front of the retina
Simple hypermetropic astigmatism with the rule; Point F (second focal line) is on the retina and Point B (first focal line) is behind the retina

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with blurred vision. Retinoscopy reveals +1.0D sphere with -2.0D cylinder at 180°. When analyzing this patient's refractive error using Sturm's conoid configuration, if we transpose this prescription to positive cylinder form and identify the focal line positions relative to the retina, what type of astigmatism does this represent and where would the two focal lines be located?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Mixed astigmatism with the rule; Point B (first focal line) is in front of the retina and Point F (second focal line) is behind the retina

questions.text: A 10-year-old emmetropic child can see clearly from infinity down to 7 cm in front of the eye. What is the amplitude of accommodation in this child?

A 2-year-old child is brought to the outpatient department by the parents who noticed an abnormal whitish glow in the child's left eye while taking photographs with flash. On examination, a white pupillary reflex is observed. What is the most common presenting feature of the suspected condition?

A 45-year-old male with type 1 diabetes mellitus of 20 years duration presents with gradual visual deterioration in both eyes. Fundus examination reveals new vessels at the disc measuring less than 1/3rd of disc diameter along with vitreous hemorrhage in the right eye. Based on the Diabetic Retinopathy Study (DRS) criteria, which of the following best defines this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. B) High-risk proliferative diabetic retinopathy

questions.text: Which extraocular muscle has intorsion as its primary action?

choices.text: Window defects with early hyperfluorescence that fades in late frames; Intravitreal anti-VEGF injection
Flower petal appearance with progressive leakage in late frames; Topical NSAID drops for 3-4 months
Ink-blot pattern with gradually increasing hyperfluorescence; Laser photocoagulation with grid pattern
Lacy hyperfluorescence with progressive leakage; Photodynamic therapy with Verteporfin

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents 6 weeks after uncomplicated phacoemulsification with gradual vision decline in the operated eye (VA 6/18, not improving with pinhole). Slit-lamp exam shows a well-centered posterior chamber IOL with clear posterior capsule. Fundus exam reveals a macular abnormality. Fundus fluorescein angiography shows a characteristic late-phase pattern. Which of the following describes the FFA finding and the appropriate initial pharmacological treatment for this condition?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Flower petal appearance with progressive leakage in late frames; Topical NSAID drops for 3-4 months

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with a painless nodular swelling on the upper eyelid. During surgical excision, the surgeon needs to identify the proper plane for dissection. The image below shows a cross-sectional anatomy of the eyelid. Which layer, marked in red in the diagram, contains the meibomian glands and provides the structural framework to the eyelid?

A 12-year-old girl presents with chronic bilateral anterior uveitis without any symptoms of pain or redness. On examination, posterior synechiae and band keratopathy are noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 6-year-old child presents with drooping of right upper eyelid since birth. On examination, levator function is 3 mm and the upper lid shows retraction when the child moves jaw to the opposite side. What is the most appropriate surgical management?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Levator excision with frontalis sling

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with progressive painless protrusion of the right eye over 6 months. On examination, there is axial proptosis with restricted ocular movements. Hertel's exophthalmometry shows 24 mm on the right side and 18 mm on the left. Visual acuity is 6/9 in the right eye. A CT scan orbit is performed. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Switch to combination antifungal therapy with steroids

questions.text: A 35-year-old diabetic male presents with acute painful proptosis, chemosis, and complete ophthalmoplegia over 48 hours. Examination reveals black eschar on nasal mucosa and eyelids. Visual acuity is hand movements. Biopsy shows nonseptate broad branching hyphae. Despite IV amphotericin B for 72 hours, there is progression with orbital apex involvement. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: The lens capsule is thinnest at the pre-equatorial region and thickest at the posterior pole
The lens capsule is thickest at the pre-equatorial region and thinnest at the posterior pole
The lens capsule is uniformly thick throughout and contains epithelium on both anterior and posterior surfaces
The lens capsule is thickest at the equatorial region and thinnest at the anterior pole

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient undergoing cataract surgery is being counseled about the procedure. The surgeon explains that during extracapsular cataract extraction, a specific part of the lens capsule will be preserved. Which of the following statements correctly describes the anatomical characteristics of the lens capsule that are relevant to this surgical technique?
questions.solution: Ans. B) The lens capsule is thickest at the pre-equatorial region and thinnest at the posterior pole

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with bilateral downward and nasal subluxation of the lens. He has a fair complexion with malar flush and exhibits poor motor control with a history of seizures. Laboratory investigation reveals a positive sodium nitroprusside test in urine. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Attempt to retrieve the nucleus with lens loop through the main incision
Complete anterior vitrectomy and cortical cleanup, refer to vitreoretinal surgeon
Convert to intracapsular cataract extraction and remove the nucleus
Extend the incision and deliver the nucleus with vectis

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient undergoes manual SICS for mature senile cataract. During surgery, while performing hydrodissection, the surgeon notices sudden deepening of the anterior chamber with loss of red reflex. The nucleus that was being mobilized is no longer visible in the anterior segment. Intraoperatively, what is the most appropriate immediate management?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Complete anterior vitrectomy and cortical cleanup, refer to vitreoretinal surgeon

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with recurrent unilateral eye pain, redness, and photophobia. Examination shows circumciliary congestion, fine stellate keratic precipitates diffusely over the cornea, heterochromia with the affected eye lighter, elevated IOP (28 mmHg), absence of posterior synechiae, and spontaneous hyphema during paracentesis. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old female presents with bilateral floaters and blurred vision for the past 3 weeks. She also reports hearing loss, tinnitus, and the recent appearance of white patches on her skin. Ocular examination reveals bilateral granulomatous panuveitis, focal exudative retinal detachment with these characteristic fundus changes. Perilimbal depigmentation noted on slit-lamp examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Iris and pars plicata of ciliary body

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with sudden onset of pain, redness, photophobia, and blurred vision in his right eye for the past 2 days. Slit-lamp examination reveals circumciliary congestion, aqueous cells and flare, and fine keratic precipitates arranged in a triangular pattern with the base at the limbus and apex directed toward the corneal center. The pupil appears constricted and irregular. Which anatomical structure is chiefly involved in this condition?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Iris and pars plicata of ciliary body

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient who underwent penetrating keratoplasty 8 months ago for advanced keratoconus presents with sudden visual loss in the grafted eye. Slit-lamp examination shows a linear demarcation advancing from the graft periphery toward the center, associated with keratic precipitates and corneal edema. The patient reports no pain or photophobia. Which clinical sign most specifically indicates the type of graft rejection in this case?

choices.text: Bowman's membrane - cannot regenerate; Descemet's membrane - can regenerate
Epithelium - cannot regenerate; Bowman's membrane - can regenerate
Descemet's membrane - cannot regenerate; Dua's layer - can regenerate
Endothelium - cannot regenerate; Bowman's membrane - can regenerate

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents 10 days after a corneal injury from a wooden stick. Slit-lamp examination with histological cross-section shows corneal wound healing. The ophthalmologist explains that one corneal layer cannot regenerate and heals by scarring, while another membrane-like layer has regenerated. Based on the image and regenerative properties, which two corneal layers are these?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Bowman's membrane - cannot regenerate; Descemet's membrane - can regenerate

choices.text: Floor stains with fluorescein, margins stain with rose bengal; topical acyclovir and avoid steroids
Margins stain with fluorescein, floor stains with rose bengal; topical steroids accelerate healing
Floor stains with rose bengal only; treatment requires only lubricants as no active virus present
Entire lesion stains uniformly with both dyes; combination antiviral-steroid therapy indicated

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with recurrent unilateral eye pain, redness, and photophobia. On slit-lamp examination with fluorescein staining, the corneal lesion shown in the image is observed. Corneal aesthesiometry reveals markedly reduced sensation. Rose bengal staining shows uptake at the lesion margins. Which statement about this condition is most accurate regarding its staining characteristics and management?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Floor stains with fluorescein, margins stain with rose bengal; topical acyclovir and avoid steroids

choices.text: Rupture of Descemet's membrane causing aqueous influx and stromal hydration
Acute endothelial decompensation due to reduced endothelial cell count
Spontaneous corneal perforation with iris prolapse requiring urgent surgery
Acute infectious keratitis secondary to chronic contact lens use

questions.text: A 24-year-old known case of keratoconus presents with sudden onset severe pain, photophobia, and marked decrease in vision. Slit-lamp examination reveals diffuse corneal edema and opacification in the affected eye. What is the underlying pathological mechanism responsible for this acute presentation?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Rupture of Descemet's membrane causing aqueous influx and stromal hydration

questions.text: Patient presents with guttae lesion in one eye and bullous keratopathy in the other eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 4-year-old child born at 32 weeks of gestation with birth weight of 1800 grams is being screened for retinopathy of prematurity (ROP). When should the first screening examination be performed?
questions.solution: Ans. B) At 4 weeks postnatal age

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with inward deviation of the right eye that has been present since 6 months of age. The deviation is constant and measures approximately 40 prism diopters. Examination reveals alternate fixation in primary gaze and cross fixation in lateral gaze. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Visual acuity less than 6/60 or central visual field less than 20 degrees in the better eye
Visual acuity less than 3/60 or counting fingers at a distance of 3 meters or central visual field less than 10 degrees
Inability to count fingers in daylight at a distance of 3 meters
Visual acuity less than 1/60 to perception of light in the better eye

questions.text: According to the National Programme for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment (NPCB), what is the definition of blindness as updated in 2017?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Visual acuity less than 3/60 or counting fingers at a distance of 3 meters or central visual field less than 10 degrees

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe ocular pain, redness, and profuse hemorrhagic discharge from both eyes for the past 24 hours. He also complains of diminished vision. On examination, subconjunctival hemorrhages are noted bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?

A 55-year-old female presents with chronic watering from the right eye with mucopurulent discharge. On regurgitation test, purulent material is expressed from the lower punctum. What is the most appropriate definitive surgical treatment?
Which of the following is the most common cause of band-shaped keratopathy?

A 19-year-old male presents with progressive blurring and distortion of vision in both eyes for the past 1 year. He reports increased glare while driving at night and frequent changes in his spectacle prescription. On slit-lamp examination, you note central corneal thinning and a subtle, brownish pigmented ring at the base of the cone. Which of the following substances is most likely responsible for the formation of this ring?

A 30-year-old patient presents with redness, pain, and photophobia in the right eye. On examination, mutton fat keratic precipitates and iris nodules are noted. What type of uveitis is this patient presenting with?

A 28-year-old male presents with bilateral lens subluxation displaced superiorly and temporally. He has tall stature, long limbs, arachnodactyly, and hyperextensible joints. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 6-year-old child presents with rapidly progressive unilateral proptosis of sudden onset over 2 weeks. On examination, there is marked lid swelling, chemosis, and restricted ocular movements. CT scan shows an irregular but well-defined mass with adjacent bone destruction in the superonasal quadrant of the orbit. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Complete non-canalization of the nasolacrimal duct
Membranous occlusion at the valve of Hasner
Bony occlusion of the nasolacrimal duct
Membranous occlusion at the upper end near lacrimal sac

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Membranous occlusion at the valve of Hasner

questions.text: A 55-year-old Type 2 diabetic patient diagnosed 5 years ago presents for routine fundus examination. On examination, microaneurysms, dot and blot hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, and venous beading are seen in all four quadrants. What is the recommended immediate management for this patient?

choices.text: Intravenous mannitol and anterior chamber paracentesis

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden painless loss of vision in the right eye that occurred over a few seconds. On examination, visual acuity is hand movements, there is a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), and fundus examination reveals a cherry red spot at the macula with pale retina and segmented blood column in retinal vessels. What is the most appropriate immediate management?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Intravenous mannitol and anterior chamber paracentesis

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient presents with gradual vision loss. On examination, IOP is 28 mmHg, and perimetry shows characteristic visual field defects. Which of the following is the earliest clinically significant visual field defect in primary open-angle glaucoma?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Small wing-shaped paracentral scotoma

questions.text: According to the World Health Organization (WHO) definition, blindness is defined as:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Visual acuity less than 3/60

choices.text: Repeat excision with bare sclera technique

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient underwent surgical excision of pterygium using the bare sclera technique. Six months later, the patient develops recurrence of the pterygium at the same site. What is the most appropriate surgical management for this recurrent pterygium to minimize the risk of further recurrence?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Excision with conjunctival autograft

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding the natural progression of CRAO?

 

  1. Optic atrophy may develop as a late sequela.
  2. Edema of the retina typically resolves over time.
  3. Spontaneous re-canalization of the artery may occur.
  4. Vision typically returns to baseline after 1–2 weeks.
Damage to which of the following structures is primarily responsible for the development of Holmes-Adie pupil?
Which of the following is the most likely cause of conjunctivitis occurring within the first 24 hours of life, and is usually self-limiting?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Chemical reaction to silver nitrate

choices.text: Just posterior to the rectus muscle insertion

questions.text: Which of the following accurately describes the thinnest region of the sclera?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Just posterior to the rectus muscle insertion

questions.text: In corneal ulcer evaluation, where should the sample for corneal scraping ideally be obtained from?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Leading edge of the ulcer

choices.text: Poor fixation and following of light

questions.text: Which of the following clinical findings is most specific for retinoblastoma as a cause of leukocoria in infants?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Calcification on B-scan or CT

choices.text: Concentric flaky deposits on the lens capsule

questions.text: Which of the following features is most characteristic of pigmentary glaucoma but not typically seen in pseudoexfoliation glaucoma?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Mid-peripheral iris transillumination defects

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant is diagnosed with bilateral congenital cataracts. Compared to a unilateral cataract, which of the following is less likely in this patient?

Match the following types of astigmatism with their corresponding descriptions:

 

Column A:

 

  1. With the rule astigmatism
  2. Against the rule astigmatism
  3. Oblique astigmatism
  4. Bioblique astigmatism

 

Column B:

 

  1. The principal meridians are at right angles to each other, with the vertical meridian more curved.
  2. The principal meridians are at right angles, but the horizontal meridian is more curved.
  3. The axes are both acute and obtuse, and neither aligns with horizontal or vertical meridians.
  4. The axes are right angles to each other but do not align with horizontal or vertical meridians.

Match each genetic syndrome to the typical direction or characteristic of lens subluxation it most commonly presents with. Each match must be justified based on the underlying pathological mechanisms.

 

Syndromes:

 

  1. Marfan Syndrome
  2. Homocystinuria
  3. Weill-Marchesani Syndrome
  4. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome

 

Ocular Manifestations: 

 

  1. Inferonasal subluxation, progressive, zonules often disrupted 
  2. Superotemporal subluxation, zonules usually intact 
  3. Downward subluxation, associated with microspherophakia 
  4. No characteristic subluxation, may have other ocular anomalies

choices.text: Indirect gonioscopy using a Goldmann lens
Direct gonioscopy using a Koeppe lens
Indirect gonioscopy using a Zeiss lens
Direct gonioscopy using a Goldmann lens

questions.text: A 63-year-old man is undergoing gonioscopy as part of his glaucoma evaluation. The examiner uses a technique requiring the patient to lie supine and directly visualizes the anterior chamber angle with high magnification. Which of the following gonioscopy types and lenses is being used in this case?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Direct gonioscopy using a Koeppe lens

choices.text: Haab’s striae caused by elevated intraocular pressure
Band keratopathy due to calcium deposition

questions.text: A 3-month-old girl presents with photophobia, excessive tearing, and eyelid spasms. Examination reveals the findings in the image, with a cup-to-disc ratio of 0.6 in both eyes. Which of the following best describes the feature visible in the image?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Haab’s striae caused by elevated intraocular pressure

questions.text: A 40-year-old myopic man presents with progressive vision loss. Examination reveals corneal pigmentation (as shown in the image), slit-like radial iris transillumination defects, and heavy pigment accumulation in the trabecular meshwork. What is the most likely inheritance pattern of this condition?

choices.text: Acanthamoeba — treated with PHMB (Polyhexamethylene Biguanide) or chlorhexidine
Acanthamoeba — treated with PHMB (Pseudo-Hexa Microbiotic Base)
Pseudomonas aeruginosa — treated with Ceftazomax Plus (pseudo name)

questions.text: A 25-year-old soft contact lens wearer presents with severe ocular pain, redness, photophobia, and watery discharge in the right eye. Slit-lamp examination reveals a ring-shaped stromal infiltrate. Corneal scraping identifies an organism strongly associated with poor contact lens hygiene. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism and appropriate treatment?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Acanthamoeba — treated with PHMB (Polyhexamethylene Biguanide)

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with redness and irritation in his left eye. Examination reveals the following lesion at the limbus. Which of the following is the best initial treatment for this condition?

choices.text: Scattered light is destroyed by mutual interference
Loss of transparency results if lattice arrangement is altered.

questions.text: Which of the following is/are true about MAURICE theory?

A 12-year-old boy presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of itching, redness, and mucous discharge from both eyes, particularly during the spring and summer months. On examination, you observe the presence of giant papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva. What type of immunologic reaction is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this condition?
Identify the abnormality:
A patient is diagnosed with left oculomotor nerve palsy. Which of the following movements is spared?
Fenretinide is a new agent under trial for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Age related Macular Degeneration

questions.text:
During an eye examination, a clinician evaluates the refractive properties of various components of a patient's eye. Arrange the following parts from highest to lowest refractive index:

 

  1. Periphery of the lens
  2. Aqueous humor
  3. Cornea
  4. Centre of the lens

A 70-year-old patient presented with complaints of defective vision in the right eye associated with erythropsia and cyanopsia. On examination it was seen that his pupil was jet black and the Purkinje image test revealed only two images. What is likely to be the conclusion after performing retinoscopy?
Which of the following is not a sign of a blow-out fracture of orbit?
The Fovea centralis is responsible for the visual acuity of a person. How much is it’s diameter?

choices.text: Increased affinity to endothelium in inferior cornea
Lipophilic nature of the suspended particles

questions.text: The following finding is noted in a patient. What is the reason behind this pattern of deposition?
A middle-aged patient who underwent perimetry had the following visual field defect. What is the site of the lesion?

A 43-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute vision loss and painful eye movements in one eye. Upon examination, a relative afferent pupillary defect is noted in the affected eye, while the optic disk appears normal. Visual field testing reveals a central scotoma in the same eye. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
